full_transcript.case_description: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb, 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb, 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves' disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9 °C (102 °F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. What is the most likely cause?

She has a keen eye for subtle signs of hormonal imbalances and is particularly skilled in diagnosing and managing hypothyroidism in newborns. Her approach is systematic and thorough, ensuring that every detail is considered before making a diagnosis.

He is meticulous in his approach, often using advanced imaging techniques to diagnose subtle heart abnormalities. His expertise lies in identifying and managing congenital heart defects, which can sometimes present with similar symptoms to hypothyroidism.

agents.persona: Dr. Patel is a pediatric infectious diseases specialist with a keen interest in neonatal infections. She is known for her ability to quickly identify and manage infections in newborns, often using a combination of clinical judgment and laboratory tests. Her approach is intuitive, allowing her to make connections between symptoms and potential causes.

agents.name: Dr. James Wilson
agents.persona: Dr. Wilson is a pediatric pulmonologist with a focus on respiratory diseases in infants. He is skilled in diagnosing and managing respiratory distress in newborns, often using a combination of clinical evaluation and specialized tests. His approach is methodical, ensuring that all respiratory symptoms are thoroughly evaluated.

agents.persona: Expert clinical evaluator specializing in diagnosis equivalence assessment with extensive knowledge across all medical specialties. Focuses on determining whether different diagnostic terms represent the same underlying medical condition.
